SG.evidence: Broadcast journalists from the PRC have been hired by Singapore's state broadcaster, which dominates the broadcast media landscape. China Communications University conducts training for media workers in collaboration with institutions in Singapore, notably the Nanyang Academy of Fine Arts, PSB Academy, the Singapore Institute of Management, and MDIS.
SG.note: One PRC-trained media personality was involved in advancing the narrative that the Russian invasion of Ukraine was the result of NATO instigation on a state-owned media outlet produced online video. That video was later removed for unclear reasons.
SG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

TW.evidence: According to Beijing's Global Media Influence report conducted by Freedom House, Chinese state-linked actors have organized trainings for online influencers to teach them skills like developing short videos and producing live shows, with the aim of attaining “online celebrity status.” According to the National Security Agency of Taiwan, these trainings for Taiwanese internet celebrities and e-commerce live broadcasters are aimed at targeting people who wield considerable influence over the content consumed by young Taiwanese. The training and exchange programs stalled during the pandemic and have gradually resumed after the travel restrictions in PRC lifted. The Wenzhou authority in Zhejiang Province, PRC, started a cross-strait training for e-commerce livestreaming in 2020. The 3rd training started in July 2022 with hybrid participation from Taiwan and Wenzhou; and the 4th training program was held in July 2023 with more than 70 on-site participation.
TW.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

BR.evidence: It was searched for evidence first through search engines and later on Brazilian media sites (O Globo, Folha de São Paulo and Estadão), on the official Brazilian press website, Diário Oficial da União, and on the website of reporters without borders, but no evidence was found of journalists, influencers or media groups receiving training in China. In addition, Empresa Brasil de Comunicação (EBC) was asked, through the Brazil's Access to Information Law, about sending personnel to receive training in China. In response, the EBC informed that despite the partnership with the China Media Group (CMG) there was no exchange of personnel for training neither from Brazil to China nor from China to Brazil.
BR.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

CZ.evidence:
The founder and owner of Czech alternative media outlet General News joined a delegation of journalists from Central and Eastern Europe to visit visit China in 2024. The group visited the China International Press Communication Center (中国国际新闻交流中心) which offers training to foreign journalists. The delegation was invited to the PRC by the China-Central and Eastern European Countries Cooperation Secretariat (中国—中东欧国家合作秘书处).
Former Czech Prime Minister Jiří Paroubek, who is an active commentator and blogger on the Czech internet , occasionally visits the PRC. However, financing of his journeys has not been disclosed.
CZ.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

EE.evidence: There is no identified journalist, media organization or online influencer who have received trainings from PRC state-owned media or PRC-connected entities.
EE.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

PL.evidence: There is no public information on the issue, confirmation of such trainings.
PL.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

VN.evidence:
We found an influencer that goes by the name Anh Nguyen with 8000+ followers. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Few" and "Insignificant" rating.
The workshop and the trip to China will be arranged by the Lancang-Mekong Cooperation Media Summit, which is being hosted by Chinese media and includes media outlets from China, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, Thailand, and Vietnam.
VN.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

NP.evidence:
A reporter of media outlet in Nepal is on the “2022 Asian Countries Mainstream Media Network Training Course(2022亚洲国家主流媒体网络研修班)” hosted by China. 

Earlier, there was a “Nepalese Media Journalist Training Course(尼泊尔媒体记者研修班)” in 2018 and 2019. However, latest information about the training course is unavailable.
NP.answerer: Answered by Sriparna Pathak, and has been reviewed by Amish Mulmi

RU.note: As far as we can see, Russian journalists from state-owned media mostly participate in bilateral media forums or dialogues (https://rg.ru/2023/09/22/26-sentiabria-kitajsko-rossijskij-dialog-molodyh-zhurnalistov.html) and new media forums (https://tass.ru/press-relizy/13076523). These events typically focus on new ways of spreading traditional media information via the internet. There is no evidence of journalists, media organizations, or online influencers in our country receiving training from PRC state-owned media or PRC-connected entities.
RU.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 3 anonymous experts.

NZ.evidence: Some of the anchors from the Chinese language channel Channel 33 received their journalism training in the PRC
NZ.answerer: Answered by Catherine Churchman, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

ZW.evidence: There are reports of journalists from state-owned media such as The Herald and Zimbabwe Broadcasting Cooperation who have received some form of training in PRC.
ZW.answerer: Answered by Ernest Mudzengi, and has been reviewed by Andronicus Sikula and Dr. Obert Hodzi

CD.evidence: In 2023 medias professional of 11 african countries have been to china to attend seminar. Among them we had journalists from DRC
CD.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Andronicus Sikula, Dr. Obert Hodzi and Christian Rumu

MY.evidence: Supported by the Foreign Affairs Office (FAO) of the government of China’s northeastern Heilongjiang Province, the training sessions illustrate how initiatives by the CCP to shape a positive global image of the country not just of national leaders and central state media, but also a wide range of actors, including local governments and educational institutions.
MY.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

TL.evidence: There is no evidence of journalists, media organizations, or influencers in Timor-Leste receiving direct training from PRC state-owned media or entities. Although media cooperation agreements exist between Timor-Leste's RTTL and Chinese state media for content digitization and sharing, no training programs by Chinese entities are mentioned.
TL.answerer: Answered by 2 anonymous experts, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

AR.evidence: The Chinese embassy has close ties to various media groups in Argentina, including socia media influencers and journalists. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "more than a few" rating. Their coordination includes publishing signed articles, giving interviews, and holding briefings. Some of the media cooperation is also based on ideological sympathies. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
AR.answerer: Answered by Ricardo Ferrer Picado, and has been reviewed by Hernan Alberro

UY.evidence: In September of 2023, journalists from Uruguay participated in the Seminar for Latin American Media Journalists, which was through the Chilean Agency for International Development Cooperation (AGCID) and the Chinese Embassy in Chile. Therefore this indicator deserves a "more than a few" rating. The journalists were able to participate through a scholarship funded by the PRC's Ministry of Commerce and the Institute for Research, and China's National Administration of Radio and Television (NRTa). Therefore, this indicator deserves a "significant" rating.
UY.note:
In July 2017, China held a two-week seminar with the objective of "increasing dialogue and cooperation" between China and Latin American countries in the journalism and media field. This seminar was organized by the Chinese Foreign Language Department and the Shandong Government Press Office. Journalists from Uruguay participated in the seminar.
https://www.pitcnt.uy/novedades/noticias/item/2245-jefes-de-prensa-de-latinoamerica-intercambiaron-en-china-experiencias-sobre-los-medios-de-comunicacion
UY.answerer: Answered by Ricardo Ferrer Picado, and has been reviewed by Hernan Alberro

SV.evidence: There is no observation of the indicator phenomenon.
SV.answerer: Answered by Eric Lemus, and has been reviewed by Julio Martinez and Alvaro Cruz

PH.evidence: From My 23 to June 5, China's Research and Training Institute of the National Radio and Television Administration (NRTA) hosted Filipino journalists and information officers from Manila and Davao for a two-week seminar and media site visits in Beijing and Nanning. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "Few" rating. Of the 12 participants, three were bloggers that were known to be sympathetic to the Dutertes; five were reporters (two were from prominent news sites Inquirer and Mindanao Times), and the rest are government communications officials. Therefore, this indicator deserves a "Significant" rating.
PH.note: Topics during the said seminar include the Development of Radio, Television and Online Audio-Video Sector of China and NRTA’s International Exchanges and Cooperation; Chinese National Conditions and a Cultural Perspective; Constructive Journalism and Development Communication in China; Media Literacy in the Information Age; Constructive Journalism and Development Communication in China; Planning and Production of Short Videos; Film and Television Culture in China; and Non-fiction Short Video Creation, Production Planning, Discussion and Production Guidance.
PH.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

TH.evidence: Thai Journalists Assocation. the country's leading journalists association has active ties with the Chinese government. They have also been invited on trips top China over the years.
TH.note: In Jan 2023, China Cultural Centre in Bangkok conducted Advanced Chinese language training for Thai Journalists Association: Link: https://cccbkk.org/advanced-chinese-training
TH.answerer: Answered by Pravit Rojanaphruk, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

MM.evidence: Journalists from state-owned media group Myanmar Radio Television took part in fully funded tours under the programme called ' A Myanmar Journalist's Experience in China'. It is significant because it is boardcasted on CRI Myanmar facebook page, which has 1.8 million followers.
MM.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

UG.evidence: A good number of journalists visiting China do so to attend training. One such example, are trainings organised by the China Publica Diplomacy Association (CPDA) like "China International Press Communication Center". While these are presented as "exchanges", they moslty involved foreign journalists visiting China, rather than Chinese journalists visiting other countries.
UG.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Agather Atuhaire

MZ.evidence: The Fredoom House report on China's influence on the media in Mozambique mentions that there are initiatives to support mozambican journalists travelling to China and funded by PRC.
MZ.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Sérgio Chichava

AO.evidence: Angolan journalists and media organisations are regularly part of trainings organised through PRC sponsored programmes like the China Africa Press Centre or the China International Press Communication Center.
AO.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

JP.evidence: There are some news that Japanese participated in media training in Japan. It does not tell how many participated, but we can assume from the sources that the number would be quite limited. There is no statistical evidence, and thus my confidence rating is 70.
JP.answerer: Answered by Maiko Ichihara, and has been reviewed by Ryohei Suzuki and Yuki Moritarni

ID.evidence: Zulfiani Lubis chief editor of Idntimes.com, an online publication targeting young Indonesians, noted that vocational training is a common way to fight terrorism, extremism, and separatism, and drew comparisons between Indonesia's and China's respective experiences in terrorism.
ID.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

KR.evidence: Short term trainings in China are annually opened for Korean journalists
KR.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

SA.evidence: A number of Saudi students received media trainings in China.
SA.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

QA.evidence: Chinese media outlets plan to open offices at Qatar Media City, with increased media cooperation and the establishment of a Chinese cultural center and Confucius Academy. However, there is no evidence indicating that Qatari journalists, media organizations, or influencers receive training from PRC entities.
QA.answerer: Answered by Muhammad Zulfikar Rakhmat, and has been reviewed by Yeta Purnama

CA.evidence: Various Canadian media outlets attended training events in China in 2022. All of these media outlets publish in Chinese language. Hosting organizations in China included OCAO (侨办), ACFROC (侨联), etc.
CA.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by Terry Glavin

KH.evidence: Yes, there is growing collaboration under the framing of "fighting misinformation."
KH.answerer: Answered by Bradley J. Murg, and has been reviewed by another 2 anonymous experts.

US.evidence: The State Department estimates that over 300 PRC state media journalists operate on US social media platforms such as X to influence public opinion. In 2023, the FBI found that the Ministry of Public Security 912 Special Project Working Group created thousands of fake online personas on social media sites, including Twitter, to target Chinese democracy activists and critics of the CCP through online harassment and threats. These online personas disseminate official PRC government propaganda and narratives to counter and overwhelm the critical speech of the Chinese activists. Therefore, this Indicator deserves a "More than a Few" rating. However, public views of China in the United States remain largely negative. Therefore, this Indicator deserves an "Insignificant" rating.
US.answerer: Answered by 1 anonymous expert, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

DE.evidence: Journalists are invited to visited the PRC but there is observation of training.
DE.answerer: Answered by Angela Stanzel, and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.

GB.evidence: There have been past observations, but no evidence of cases since 2022.
GB.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Sam Dunning and Andrew Yeh

AU.evidence: There is no evidence of Australian influencers or journalists receiving training from PRC-connected entities within the reporting period.
AU.answerer: Answered by Leo Shaw, and has been reviewed by Kevin Mooney and Andrew Yeh

IL.evidence: To the best of the respondents' knowledge, not during the specified timeframe of January 2022 to July 2023, and never in the past.
IL.answerer: Answered by The Institute for National Security Studies (INSS), and has been reviewed by another 1 anonymous expert.
